company.name: ASUSTeK Computer, Inc.
company.business_description: ASUSTeK Computer, Inc. is a hardware manufacturer that designs and sells routers and related software and services for consumer use. The company controls U.S. marketing and advertising for its routers, develops and distributes software updates, and sells routers through a wholly owned U.S. subsidiary via third-party retailers.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

complaint.factual_background: ASUSTeK Computer, Inc. (ASUS), a Taiwanese hardware manufacturer, sold consumer routers with cloud features (AiCloud and AiDisk) while marketing them as secure platforms for storing and accessing sensitive personal information. ASUS failed to implement basic security measures, leaving routers vulnerable to authentication bypass, password disclosure, and cross-site request forgery attacks. The company also deployed default settings that exposed consumers' USB storage devices to unauthenticated internet access, and provided a firmware upgrade tool that falsely indicated routers were running the latest firmware when they were not. Despite receiving multiple reports from security researchers about these vulnerabilities beginning in mid-2013, ASUS delayed notifying consumers and taking corrective action for months. By early 2014, hackers had exploited these flaws to access the USB storage devices of thousands of consumers and publicly posted login credentials for over 3,000 AiCloud accounts.

representations_made.description: Claimed that its routers include security features (such as SPI intrusion detection and DoS protection) and can protect computers from unauthorized access, hacking, and virus attacks, and instructed consumers to enable the firewall to protect against hackers
representations_made.quoted_text: appliances, against malicious incoming traffic from the internet. Respondent marketed its routers as including security features such as “SPI intrusion detection” and “DoS protection,” advertised that its routers could “protect computers from any unauthorized access, hacking, and virus attacks” (see Exh. A, p. 1 of 2), and instructed consumers to “enable the [router’s] firewall to protect your local network against attacks from hackers” (see Exh. A, p. 2 of 2).

representations_made.description: Marketed AiCloud as a 'private personal cloud' with 'indefinite storage and increased privacy,' and as 'the most complete, accessible, and secure cloud platform,' and described it as 'your secure space'
representations_made.quoted_text: 7. In August 2012, ASUS introduced and began marketing a feature known as AiCloud on its routers. Respondent publicized AiCloud as a “private personal cloud for selective file sharing” that featured “indefinite storage and increased privacy” (see Exh. C, p. 1 of 6). In the following months, ASUS provided software updates for certain older router models to add the AiCloud feature, which respondent touted as “the most complete, accessible, and secure cloud platform” (see Exh. C, p. 2 of 6). 8. Described as “your secure space,” AiCloud allows consumers to plug a USB storage

representations_made.description: Promoted AiDisk as a way to 'safely secure and access your treasured data through your router'
representations_made.quoted_text: (“FTP”) server. Despite the fact that FTP does not support transit encryption, since at least 2012 respondent has promoted AiDisk as a way to “safely secure and access your treasured data through your router” (see Exh. E). In addition to transferring files unencrypted, the AiDisk software included a number of other design flaws that placed consumers’ sensitive personal information at risk.

representations_made.description: Represented through the firmware upgrade tool that consumers could rely on it to accurately indicate whether their router is using the most current firmware, displaying a message that the router is checking for updates
representations_made.quoted_text: 27. The admin console includes a tool that ostensibly allows consumers to check whether their router is using the most current firmware (“firmware upgrade tool”). When consumers click on the “Check” button, the tool indicates that the “router is checking the ASUS server for the firmware update” (see Exh. H).

counts.title: Router Security Misrepresentations
counts.representation: Respondent represented, expressly or by implication, that it took reasonable steps to ensure that its routers could protect consumers' local networks from attack, including by marketing security features such as SPI intrusion detection, DoS protection, and firewall capabilities.
counts.fact: Respondent did not take reasonable steps to ensure that its routers could protect consumers' local networks from attack, as it failed to perform pre-release testing, implement protections against known vulnerabilities such as CSRF, and maintain adequate processes for addressing reported security issues.
counts.conclusion: The representation set forth in Paragraph 37 is false or misleading.

counts.title: AiCloud Security Misrepresentations
counts.representation: Respondent represented, expressly or by implication, that it took reasonable steps to ensure that its AiCloud feature is a secure means for a consumer to access sensitive personal information, marketing it as a 'private personal cloud' with 'increased privacy' and 'the most complete, accessible, and secure cloud platform.'
counts.fact: Respondent did not take reasonable steps to ensure that its AiCloud feature is a secure means for a consumer to access sensitive personal information, as AiCloud contained authentication bypass and password disclosure vulnerabilities, and respondent failed to timely notify consumers or provide fixes despite knowing of the vulnerabilities.
counts.conclusion: The representation set forth in Paragraph 39 is false or misleading.

counts.title: AiDisk Security Misrepresentations
counts.representation: Respondent represented, expressly or by implication, that it took reasonable steps to ensure that its AiDisk feature is a secure means for a consumer to access sensitive personal information, promoting it as a way to 'safely secure and access your treasured data through your router.'
counts.fact: Respondent did not take reasonable steps to ensure that its AiDisk feature is a secure means for a consumer to access sensitive personal information, as AiDisk used unencrypted FTP, had insecure default settings that allowed unauthenticated internet access to consumers' USB storage devices, and respondent failed to act on multiple security researcher warnings for months.
counts.conclusion: The representation set forth in Paragraph 41 is false or misleading.

counts.title: Firmware Upgrade Tool Misrepresentations
counts.representation: Respondent represented, expressly or by implication, that consumers can rely upon the firmware upgrade tool to accurately indicate whether their router is using the most current firmware.
counts.fact: Consumers cannot rely upon the firmware upgrade tool to accurately indicate whether their router is using the most current firmware, because ASUS repeatedly failed to update the firmware list on its server, causing the tool to falsely report that the router's firmware was already up to date when newer, security-critical updates were available.
counts.conclusion: The representation set forth in Paragraph 43 is false or misleading.

counts.title: Unfair Security Practices
counts.representation: Respondent offered routers to consumers for the purpose of protecting their local networks and accessing sensitive personal information, while failing to take reasonable steps to secure the router software.
counts.fact: Respondent's failure to take reasonable steps to secure the software for its routers caused or was likely to cause substantial injury to consumers that was not outweighed by countervailing benefits to consumers or competition and was not reasonably avoidable by consumers themselves.
counts.conclusion: Respondent's actions constitute an unfair act or practice in violation of Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

definitions.respondent: ASUSTeK Computer, Inc., corporation, and its subsidiaries and divisions in the United States, and successors and assigns.
definitions.Clear(ly) and conspicuous(ly): means that a required disclosure is difficult to miss (i.e., easily noticeable) and easily understandable by ordinary consumers, including in all of the following ways: A. In any communication that is solely visual or solely audible, the disclosure must be made through the same means through which the communication is presented. In any communication made through both visual and audible means, such as a television advertisement, the disclosure must be presented simultaneously in both the visual and audible portions of the communication, even if the representation requiring the disclosure is made in only one means. B. A visual disclosure, by its size, contrast, location, the length of time it appears, and other characteristics, must stand out from any accompanying text or other visual elements so that it is easily noticed, read, and understood. C. An audible disclosure, including by telephone or streaming video, must be delivered in a volume, speed, and cadence sufficient for ordinary consumers to easily hear and understand it. D. In any communication using an interactive electronic medium, such as the Internet or software, the disclosure must be unavoidable. E. The disclosure must use diction and syntax understandable to ordinary consumers. F. The disclosure must comply with these requirements in each medium through which it is received, including all electronic devices and face-to-face communications. G. The disclosure must not be contradicted or mitigated by, or inconsistent with, anything else in the communication.
definitions.Commerce: shall mean commerce among the several States or with foreign nations, or in any Territory of the United States or in the District of Columbia, or between any such Territory and another, or between any such Territory and any State or foreign nation, or between the District of Columbia and any State or Territory or foreign nation, as defined in Section 4 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 44.
definitions.Covered Device: shall mean (a) any router, or device for which the primary purpose is connecting other client devices to a network, developed by respondent, directly or indirectly, that is marketed to consumers in the United States and (b) the software used to access, operate, manage, or configure such router or other device subject to part (a) of this definition, including, but not limited to, the firmware, web or mobile applications, and any related online services, that are advertised, developed, branded, or provided by respondent, directly or indirectly, for use with, or as compatible with, the router or other device.
definitions.Covered Information: shall mean any individually-identifiable information from or about an individual consumer collected by respondent through a Covered Device or input into, stored on, captured with, accessed, or transmitted through a Covered Device, including but not limited to (a) a first and last name; (b) a home or other physical address; (c) an email address or other online contact information; (d) a telephone number; (e) a Social Security number; (f) financial information; (g) an authentication credential, such as a username or password; (h) photo, video, or audio files; (i) the contents of any communication, the names of any websites sought, or the information entered into any website.
definitions.Default Settings: shall mean any configuration option on a Covered Device that respondent preselects, presets, or prefills for the consumer.
definitions.Software Update: shall mean any update designed to address a Security Flaw.
definitions.Security Flaw: is a software vulnerability or design flaw in a Covered Device that creates a material risk of (a) unauthorized access to or modification of any Covered Device, (b) the unintentional exposure by a consumer of Covered Information, or (c) the unauthorized disclosure, misuse, loss, alteration, destruction, or other compromise of Covered Information.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent, expressly or by implication, the security of its Covered Devices, the protection of Covered Information, the ability to use a Covered Device to secure a network, or the up-to-date status of a Covered Device's software.

requirements.description: Must not misrepresent the extent to which respondent or its products or services maintain and protect the security of any Covered Device or the security, privacy, confidentiality, or integrity of any Covered Information
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS ORDERED that respondent and its officers, agents, representatives, and employees, directly or indirectly, in or affecting commerce, must not misrepresent in any manner, expressly or by implication: Page 3 of 9 A. The extent to which respondent or its products or services maintain and protect: 1. The security of any Covered Device; 2. The security, privacy, confidentiality, or integrity of any Covered Information;

requirements.description: Must not misrepresent the extent to which a consumer can use a Covered Device to secure a network
requirements.quoted_text: B. The extent to which a consumer can use a Covered Device to secure a network; and

requirements.description: Must not misrepresent the extent to which a Covered Device is using up-to-date software
requirements.quoted_text: C. The extent to which a Covered Device is using up-to-date software.

provisions.title: Comprehensive Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive, fully documented security program reasonably designed to address security risks for Covered Devices and protect Covered Information, including specific administrative, technical, and physical safeguards.

requirements.description: Establish and implement, no later than the date of service of this order, and thereafter maintain, a comprehensive security program reasonably designed to address security risks related to Covered Devices and protect Covered Information, fully documented in writing
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent must, no later than the date of service of this order, establish and implement, and thereafter maintain, a comprehensive security program that is reasonably designed to (1) address security risks related to the development and management of new and existing Covered Devices, and (2) protect the privacy, security, confidentiality, and integrity of Covered Information. Such program, the content and implementation of which must be fully documented in writing, must contain administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to respondent’s size and complexity, the nature and scope of respondent’s activities, and the sensitivity of the Covered Device’s function or the Covered Information, including:
requirements.deadline: date of service of this order

requirements.description: Designate an employee or employees to coordinate and be accountable for the security program
requirements.quoted_text: A. The designation of an employee or employees to coordinate and be accountable for the security program;

requirements.description: Identify material internal and external risks to the security of Covered Devices that could result in unauthorized access or modification, and assess the sufficiency of safeguards in place to control these risks
requirements.quoted_text: B. The identification of material internal and external risks to the security of Covered Devices that could result in unauthorized access to or unauthorized modification of a Covered Device, and assessment of the sufficiency of any safeguards in place to control these risks;

requirements.description: Identify material internal and external risks to the privacy, security, confidentiality, and integrity of Covered Information that could result in unintentional exposure or unauthorized disclosure/misuse/loss/compromise, and assess the sufficiency of safeguards in place
requirements.quoted_text: C. The identification of material internal and external risks to the privacy, security, confidentiality, and integrity of Covered Information that could result in the unintentional exposure of such information by consumers or the unauthorized disclosure, misuse, loss, alteration, destruction, or other compromise of such information, and assessment of the sufficiency of any safeguards in place to control these risks;

requirements.description: Risk assessments must at minimum consider risks in: employee training and management (including secure engineering and defensive programming); product design, development, and research; secure software design, development, and testing including Default Settings; review and response to third-party security vulnerability reports; and prevention, detection, and response to attacks, intrusions, or system failures
requirements.quoted_text: D. At a minimum, the risk assessments required by Subparts B and C must include consideration of risks in each area of relevant operation, including, but not limited to: (1) employee training and management, including in secure engineering and defensive programming; (2) product design, development, and research; (3) secure software design, development, and testing, including for Default Settings; (4) review, assessment, and response to third-party security vulnerability reports, and (5) prevention, detection, and response to attacks, intrusions, or systems failures;

requirements.description: Design and implement reasonable safeguards to control identified risks, including through reasonable and appropriate software security testing techniques such as vulnerability and penetration testing, security architecture reviews, code reviews, and other tests to verify access to Covered Devices and Covered Information is restricted consistent with a user's security settings
requirements.quoted_text: E. The design and implementation of reasonable safeguards to control the risks identified through risk assessment, including through reasonable and appropriate software security testing techniques, such as (1) vulnerability and penetration testing; (2) security architecture reviews; (3) code reviews; and (4) other reasonable and appropriate assessments, audits, reviews, or other tests to identify potential security failures and verify that access to Covered Devices and Covered Information is restricted consistent with a user’s security settings;

requirements.description: Regularly test or monitor the effectiveness of safeguards' key controls, systems, and procedures
requirements.quoted_text: F. Regular testing or monitoring of the effectiveness of the safeguards’ key controls, systems, and procedures;

requirements.description: Develop and use reasonable steps to select and retain service providers capable of maintaining security practices consistent with this order, and require service providers by contract to implement and maintain appropriate safeguards consistent with this order
requirements.quoted_text: G. The development and use of reasonable steps to select and retain service providers capable of maintaining security practices consistent with this order, and requiring service providers by contract to implement and maintain appropriate safeguards consistent with this order; and

requirements.description: Evaluate and adjust the security program in light of testing and monitoring results, any material changes to respondent's operations or business arrangements, or any other circumstances that may have a material impact on the effectiveness of the security program
requirements.quoted_text: H. The evaluation and adjustment of respondent’s security program in light of the results of the testing and monitoring required by Subpart F, any material changes to respondent’s operations or business arrangements, or any other circumstances that respondent knows or has reason to know may have a material impact on the effectiveness of the security program.

The reporting period for the Assessments must cover: (1) the first one hundred eighty (180) days after service of the order for the initial Assessment; and (2) each two (2) year period thereafter for twenty (20) years after service of the order for the biennial Assessments. provisions.title: Security Flaw Notification and Consumer Registration
provisions.summary: Respondent must clearly and conspicuously notify consumers when a Software Update is available or when mitigation steps exist for a Security Flaw, through multiple channels, and must provide consumers an opportunity to register contact information to receive such notifications during initial device setup.

requirements.description: Notify consumers Clearly and Conspicuously when a Software Update is available or when respondent is aware of reasonable mitigation steps for a Security Flaw, explaining how to install the update or mitigate the flaw and the risks of not doing so
requirements.quoted_text: A. Notify consumers, Clearly and Conspicuously, when a Software Update is available, or when respondent is aware of reasonable steps that a consumer could take to mitigate a Security Flaw. The notice must explain how to install the Software Update, or otherwise mitigate the Security Flaw, and the risks to the consumer’s Covered Device or Covered Information if the consumer chooses not to install the available Software Update or take the recommended steps to mitigate the Security Flaw. Notice must be provided through at least each of the following

requirements.description: Post a Clear and Conspicuous notice on at least the primary consumer-facing website and, to the extent feasible, on the user interface of any affected Covered Device
requirements.quoted_text: 1. Posting of a Clear and Conspicuous notice on at least the primary, consumer-facing website of respondent and, to the extent feasible, on the user interface of any Covered Device that is affected;

requirements.description: Directly inform consumers who register (or have registered) a Covered Device with respondent by email, text message, push notification, or another similar direct notification method
requirements.quoted_text: 2. Directly informing consumers who register, or who have registered, a Covered Device with respondent, by email, text message, push notification, or another similar method of providing notifications directly to consumers; and

requirements.description: Inform consumers who contact respondent to complain or inquire about any aspect of their purchased Covered Device
requirements.quoted_text: 3. Informing consumers who contact respondent to complain or inquire about any aspect of the Covered Device they have purchased.

requirements.description: Provide consumers an opportunity to register an email address, phone number, device, or other information during initial setup or configuration of a Covered Device to receive security notifications; registration must not be dependent upon or defaulted to agreeing to receive non-security notifications or advertising; respondent may provide an opt-out option
requirements.quoted_text: B. Provide consumers with an opportunity to register an email address, phone number, device, or other information during the initial setup or configuration of a Covered Device, in order to receive the security notifications required by this Part. The consumer’s registration of such information must not be dependent upon or defaulted to an agreement to receive non-security related notifications or any other communications, such as advertising. Notwithstanding this requirement, respondent may provide an option for consumers to opt-out of receiving such security-related notifications.

provisions.summary: The order terminates on July 18, 2036, or twenty years from the most recent date the U.S. or the Commission files a complaint in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.

requirements.description: Order terminates on July 18, 2036, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date the United States or the Commission files a complaint in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later, subject to exceptions for parts terminating in fewer than twenty years, respondents not named in such complaint, and orders that have already terminated
requirements.quoted_text: This order will terminate on July 18, 2036, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying consent decree) in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later; provided, however, that the filing of such a complaint will not affect the duration of: A. Any Part in this order that terminates in fewer than twenty (20) years; B. This order’s application to any respondent that is not named as a defendant in such complaint; and C. This order if such complaint is filed after the order has terminated pursuant to this Part. Page 8 of 9 Provided, further, that if such complaint is dismissed or a federal court rules that respondent did not violate any provision of the order, and the dismissal or ruling is either not appealed or upheld on appeal, then the order as to such respondent will terminate according to this Part as though the complaint had never been filed, except that the order will not terminate between the date such complaint is filed and the later of the deadline for appealing such dismissal or ruling and the date such dismissal or ruling is upheld on appeal.
requirements.deadline: July 18, 2036 or 20 years from most recent federal court complaint, whichever is later
